conclusion: Looking at the P-V diagram, I'll analyze a complete cycle of the ideal gas going through adiabatic and isochoric processes.
Process b→c is an isochoric heating process represented by a vertical line upward at constant volume.
Process c→d is an adiabatic expansion process represented by a curved line decreasing from c to d.
Process d→a is an isochoric cooling process represented by a vertical line downward at constant volume.
Process a→b is an adiabatic compression process represented by a curved line increasing from a to b.

premise: Volume is constant, pressure increases, temperature increases, work done = 0 (since ΔV = 0), From the First Law of Thermodynamics (ΔU = Q - W), Since W = 0, Q = ΔU > 0
conclusion: Heat is absorbed by the system during process b→c.

premise: By definition, adiabatic processes have no heat transfer, Q = 0, Work is done by the system (W > 0), ΔU = -W < 0 (internal energy decreases)
conclusion: There is no heat transfer during process c→d.

premise: Volume is constant, pressure decreases, temperature decreases, work done = 0 (since ΔV = 0), From ΔU = Q - W, Since W = 0, Q = ΔU < 0
conclusion: Heat is released by the system during process d→a.

premise: By definition, adiabatic processes have no heat transfer, Q = 0, Work is done on the system (W < 0), ΔU = -W > 0 (internal energy increases)
conclusion: There is no heat transfer during process a→b.

premise: Heat absorbed: Only during process b→c, Heat released: Only during process d→a
conclusion: To determine which is greater, compare the magnitude of temperature changes.

premise: For b→c: ΔT₁ = T_c - T_b (temperature increase), For d→a: ΔT₂ = T_d - T_a (temperature decrease)
conclusion: The temperature change from d→a is smaller than from b→c.

premise: For an ideal gas in an isochoric process: Q = nCv·ΔT, So |Q_absorbed| > |Q_released|
conclusion: The amount of heat absorbed is greater than the amount of heat released.
